title: Video shows moment driver tells cop he is with El Chapo's son and avoids inspection at checkpoint
text:
A driver avoided an inspection at a checkpoint after telling a police officer he was an associate of El Chapo's son, Ovidio Guzmán.

Video footage of the shocking exchange went viral this week after the driver slowed down and told a police officer in the Mexican resort town of Mazatlán that he was an acquaintance of Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán's son.

'We're Ovidio's people,' the driver nonchalantly told the law enforcement agent.

The cop responded by telling the motorist, 'safe travels,' before the man sped off.

The alarming video served as proof of how divided Mexico is less than a week after Ovidio was arrested in Culiacán last Thursday and immediately released by the government after the Sinaloa Cartel outnumbered the military and launched a war-like attack that left at least 11 people dead and 16 people injured.

Mexico President Andrés Manuel López Obrador said Monday his government still intends to arrest Ovidio Guzmán, son of drug lord and co-founder of the Sinaloa Cartel, once it can do so safely and not risk the lives of innocent people.

A driver records the moment he told a police officer at a checkpoint in the Mexican resort town of Mazatlán that he was an acquaintance of Ovidio Guzmán, El Chapo's son. The incident occurred after Ovidio was captured by the Mexican military last Thursday and released hours later

Ovidio Guzmán was arrested in Culiacán last Thursday and immediately released by the government after the Sinaloa Cartel outnumbered the military and launched a war-like attack that left at least eight people dead and 16 people injured

Mexico President Andrés Manuel López Obrador said he is committed to the arrest of Ovidio Guzmán as long as no innocent lives are put at risk

López Obrador said the decision to free Guzmán halted the shootings and saved lives, and he would order another apprehension provided there is an arrest warrant for the operation and that the public is not put in danger.

'People's lives must be looked after,' he said.

Guzmán is wanted on a United States arrest warrant after he and his brother were indicted in 2018 in Washington on charges of trafficking cocaine, methamphetamine and marijuana.

The indictment was unsealed on February 13 and covered the period from April 2008 to April 2018. At the time, the brothers' father, El Chapo, was running the Sinaloa cartel with co-founder Ismael 'El Mayo' Zambada.

The criminal organization is now said to be run by El Chapo's two other sons, Iván Archivaldo Guzmán and Jesús Alfredo Guzmán, alongside Zambada.

Sources told the New York Times that after Iván was captured during the raid last week.

Iván was said to have organized what would become the substantial show of force that dragged on for eight hours, all in an effort to get his Ovidio released.

Mexicans have been at odds over the decision to free Ovidio and widely skeptical over the government's ability to contain escalating violence, according to an October 18-20 phone survey of 400 adults published on Monday by newspaper Reforma.

It found that 49% of respondents disagreed with the decision to release Ovidio, while 45% agreed with it. The poll also showed 56% of respondents felt that organized crime was stronger than the government, while one third took the opposite view.

In Culiacán, where terrified residents dove to the floor or hid behind walls to escape the hail of gunfire, many breathed a sigh of relief that the government had relented.

At least 6,000 soldiers stepped foot in the northwestern city to reinforce security.

At least 6,000 soldiers stepped foot in the northwestern city of Culiacán to reinforce security

Municipal cops walk the streets of Culiacán during a class between armed groups and the Mexican military

Videos (as seen above) emerged on social media of purported members of the Sinaloa Cartel taking to the streets with machine guns and grenade launchers

'Now, three or four days afterward, people are saying it's good they didn't arrest him,' said Juan Carlos Ayala, a Culiacán resident and Sinaloa University professor who studies the sociology of drug trafficking.

'Beside the possibility of a massacre, it's good they didn't arrest him, because, in the end, this group (the Sinaloa cartel) is a necessary evil.'

Other voices continued to condemn the government's decision as a capitulation to drug cartels.

'The rule of law has given way to the rule of force,' said Luis González Pérez, head of the country's National Human Rights Commission.

'Authorities who give up doing their job because of some individuals' resistance, that is the best recipe for continuing impunity and perpetuating violence,'González Pérez added.

Marko Cortes, leader of the opposition National Action Party, said that 'the Mexican government was subjugated, forced to its knees, humiliated by a drug cartel.'

'By freeing the son of Chapo Guzmán, the Mexican people were condemned to suffering greater threats to their lives, peace and property,' Cortes said.

'Sinaloa and other states were condemned to being ruled by drug traffickers.'
description: A driver in the Mexican resort town of Mazatlán recorded the moment he told a cop he was connected to El Chapo's son and was allowed to drive away from a checkpoint.
